Package edu.umd.cs.psl.application.learning.weight.random

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    FirstOrderMetropolisRandOM
    A MetropolisRandOM learning algorithm that samples one weight for all GroundCompatibilityKernels with the same parent CompatibilityKernel.
    FirstOrderSliceRandOM  
    GroundIncompatibilityMetropolisRandOM
    A GroundMetropolisRandOM learning algorithm which scores the likelihood of a sample using the distance in total (unweighted) incompatibility space grouped by CompatibilityKernel between the sample and the observations.
    GroundMetropolisRandOM
    A MetropolisRandOM learning algorithm that samples a different weight for each GroundCompatibilityKernel but all those with the same parent CompatibilityKernel share a mean and a variance.
    GroundSliceRandOM
    A SliceRandOM learning algorithm that samples a different weight for each GroundCompatibilityKernel but all those with the same parent CompatibilityKernel share a mean and a variance.
    HardEMRandOM
    Learns new weights for the CompatibilityKernels in a Model using hard EM RandOM learning.
    IncompatibilityMetropolisRandOM
    A FirstOrderMetropolisRandOM learning algorithm which scores the likelihood of a sample using the distance in total (unweighted) incompatibility space grouped by CompatibilityKernel between the sample and the observations.
    IncompatibilitySliceRandOM
    A FirstOrderSliceRandOM learning algorithm which scores the likelihood of a sample using the distance in total (unweighted) incompatibility space grouped by CompatibilityKernel between the sample and the observations.
    MetropolisRandOM
    Abstract class that learns new weights for the CompatibilityKernels in a Model using Metropolis MCEM RandOM learning.
    SliceRandOM
    Abstract class that learns new weights for the CompatibilityKernels in a Model using slice-sampling MCEM RandOM learning.
    UnforgivingGroundSliceRandOM
    A GroundSliceRandOM learning algorithm that constrains the ground truth to be within an L1-ball centered on the mode of the energy function's optimum.
